body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

I tried to run the next script using WriteLine method in v7.4:
```
Function Test {
       $i = 3
       $j = 0
    [Console]::WriteLine("j={0} i={1}", $j,$i)
    }
Test
```	 
 


### Expected behavior

```console
j=0 i=3
```


### Actual behavior

```console
Error Exception is raised:
```


### Error details

```console
MethodException:
Line |
   4 |      [Console]::WriteLine("j={0} i={2}", $j,$i)
     |      ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
     | Multiple ambiguous overloads found for "WriteLine" and the argument count: "3".
```


The workaround solution to fix this issue is using splat parameters as :
```
 $args= @($j,$i)
 [Console]::WriteLine("j={0} i={1}",$args)  # working fine
```	
args in c# is params type.
```


### Environment data

body:
<!-- Anything that looks like this is a comment and can't be seen after the Pull Request is created. -->

## PR Context

As originally propoesd in #12305, this PR adds a new `-Duration` parameter to the `Start-Sleep` cmdlet: 

```powershell
$duration = New-TimeSpan -Seconds 2

# -Duration accepts a [timespan] value
Start-Sleep -Duration $duration

# Supports positional binding
Start-Sleep $duration

# As well as pipeline binding
$duration |Start-Sleep
```

The existing parameter sets of `Start-Sleep` remain the same, and I have not changed the `DefaultParameterSetName`, but the pipeline binding _does_ interferes with the existing (buggy/counter-intuitive) binding behavior:
```
$ts = New-TimeSpan -Seconds 62 
$ts |Start-Sleep 
```

This PR also adds range validation support for `[timespan]` values via `[ValidateRange()]`:
```powershell
function Test-TimeMachine {
  param(
    # The time machine can only go back in time
    [ValidateRange('NonPositive')]
    [timespan]$Distance
  )
  
  # time-travel $Distance and back again
}
```

Strict range validation is not of much immediate use, but in a possible future with timespan literals we could do:
```powershell
function Request-Vacation {
  param(
    [ValidateRange(1d, 60d)]
    [timespan]$Duration
  )
  
  # ...
}
```

<!-- Summarize your PR between here and the checklist. -->

## PR Context

I believe this change is reasonable to make **without wrapping in an Experimental Feature** - the behavior that we're breaking ("piped `[timespan]` values are interpreted as seconds % 60") is rather counter-intuitive and deceptive. 

<!-- Provide a little reasoning as to why this Pull Request helps and why you have opened it. -->

title: New Parameter: Start-Sleep [-Duration] <timespan>

body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

As a user I want to be able to do a full compare between two lists of objects. When one of the lists is empty, that would mean all the objects in the other list are different. This functionality can be used to build a sync deployment feature, where there is a defined list and an implemented list. 

On first run the implemented list would be empty, and the defined list is not empty. Run it through the compare and use the SideIndicators to determine which items should be created, and which items should be removed. On further runs, the compare will still work to add new defined items, and remove items that are no longer defined.

Currently an empty difference or reference object returns nothing, and $null returns an error. To avoid breaking issues, the new behavior could be implemented with a switch Compare-Object -AllowNullOrEmpty.

### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)



``` pwsh
@(@{v=1}) |
  Compare-Object `
    -ReferenceObject @(@{v=1},@{v=2},@{v=3}) `
    -PassThru `
    -IncludeEqual |
 select v, SideIndicator

# Existing behavior:
v SideIndicator
- -------------
1 ==
2 <=
3 <=
```
``` pwsh
@() |
Compare-Object `
    -ReferenceObject @(@{v=1},@{v=2},@{v=3}) `
    -Passthru `
    -IncludeEqual |
select v, SideIndicator

# existing behavior returns

# wanted behavior returns 
v SideIndicator
- -------------
1 <=
2 <=
3 <=
```

``` pwsh


$null |
Compare-Object `
    -ReferenceObject @(@{v=1},@{v=2},@{v=3}) `
    -Passthru `
    -IncludeEqual |
select v, SideIndicator

# existing behavior returns
Cannot bind argument to parameter 'DifferenceObject' because it is null.
# wanted behavior returns 
v SideIndicator
- -------------
1 <=
2 <=
3 <=

labels.description: the issue is more of a feature request than a bug
labels.name: Issue-Enhancement

# PR Summary
Updated the background invocation `&` operator to use -WorkingDirectory parameter when starting a new job. 

Fix #10515

<!-- Summarize your PR between here and the checklist. -->

## PR Context

<!-- Provide a little reasoning as to why this Pull Request helps and why you have opened it. -->
Previously, `Set-Location` was appended to the script block of `Start-Job` in order to set the working directory of a new job invoked by the background invocation operator `&`. Now that `Start-Job` accepts a `-WorkingDirectory` parameter that sets the working directory of the new job, it makes sense to update the code for using the background invocation operator to use the new way of setting the working directory of a new job.

body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

Static parameters can easily be defined declarative inside a param() structure.
Dyamic parameter is not directly supported and must be programmed inside a dynamicparam section of a scriptblock. This requires deep knowledge of intrinsic types and concepts.

By adding a new attribute [Dynamic()], parameters can easily be declared as being dynamic. The attribute could take a scriptblock as argument to specify the condition under which the dynamic parameter would show.

```powershell
param
(
    # regular static parameter
    [string]
    $Normal,
        
    # show -Lunch only at 11 a.m. or later
    [Dynamic({(Get-Date).Hour -ge 11})]
    [switch]
    $Lunch,
        
    # show -Mount only when -Path refers to a local path (and not a UNC path)
    [string]
    $Path,
        
    [Dynamic({$PSBoundParameters['Path'] -match '^[a-z]:'})]
    [switch]
    $Mount
)
```

Here is a working example and a proof of concept (hosted in the gallery) that shows how dynamic parameters could be leveraged this way:

https://github.com/TobiasPSP/Modules.dynpar/blob/main/README.md

It would be awesome if both the attribute `[Dynamic()]` and the auto-generation of the code would one day be natively integrated in PowerShell so users would just need to choose which of their parameters should be dynamic, and when.

### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

Technical implementation available here: https://github.com/TobiasPSP/Modules.dynpar/blob/main/README.md

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

**On Windows**

1. Open an elevated pwsh session, and create 2 symbolic links as follows in a folder:
    ```
    New-Item -ItemType SymbolicLink -Path pwsh-symlink -Value $pshome\pwsh.exe
    New-Item -ItemType SymbolicLink -Path pwsh-double-link -Value .\pwsh-symlink
    ```
3. Under the same folder, run `.\pwsh-symlink`, and you will see pwsh console window pops up.
4. Under the same folder, run `.\pwsh-double-link`, and you will see the "How do you want to open this file" window pops up.

> Note: `Start-Process` doesn't use the final target of a symbolic link either.

----------------------

However, **it works fine on Unix**

1. Create 2 symbolic links as follows in a folder:
    ```
    /bin/ln -s /opt/microsoft/powershell/7/pwsh pwsh-link
    /bin/ln -s /home/<user>/tmp/pwsh-link /home/<user>/tmp/pwsh-double
    ```
2. Under the same folder, run `./pwsh-link -c 1+1`, and you will get `2` printed out as the result.
3. Under the same folder, run `./pwsh-double -c 1+1`, and you will get `2` printed out as the result.

### Expected behavior

```console
On Windows:
1. pwsh should know that `pwsh-symlink` is actually a console application, and run into with the current console.
2. pwsh should be able to run `pwsh-double-link`, just like on Unix platforms.
```


### Actual behavior

```console
On Windows
1. pwsh opens `pwsh-symlink` in a separate console window, which means it doesn't use the link target to check if it's a console application, and thus starts the process with 'UseShellExecute = true'.
2. pwsh cannot run `pwsh-double-link`, because when using `UseShellExecute`, the Shell automatically uses the immediate link target of a symbolic link file, but doesn't do recursive resolution when the immediate link target is again a symbolic link.
```


### Error details

_No response_

### Environment data

```powershell
The latest build from master, and happen on all 7.2.0-preview.9 as well
```


### Visuals

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/127450/135180968-dc1fc21c-94db-4c11-a4f9-c02a42c9be4f.png)


![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/127450/135180988-ff7ddcad-b0b6-46c9-aac7-e8e9a5cda252.png)

### Steps to reproduce

Write a script, in which the `#Requires -Modules` statement is used. This example reflects the usage how I was made aware of this issue:
```powershell
#Requires -Modules VMware.VimAutomation.Core, ActiveDirectory

Connect-VIServer vcenter.local

Get-ADUser -Filter *
```

The modules are installed and the CmdLets are working if used manually:
```powershell
PS C:\> Get-Module VMware.VimAutomation.Core

ModuleType Version    PreRelease Name                                ExportedCommands
---------- -------    ---------- ----                                ----------------
Script     12.0.0.15…            VMware.VimAutomation.Core           {Add-PassthroughD...}
```
```powershell
PS C:\> Get-Module ActiveDirectory

ModuleType Version    PreRelease Name                                ExportedCommands
---------- -------    ---------- ----                                ----------------
Script     1.0                   ActiveDirectory                     {Add-ADCentralAcce...}
```

The `VMware.PowerCLI` module is installed directly as a Core module, the `ActiveDirectory` module uses the implicit remoting functionality and uses PowerShell 5.1
The problem with the directly loaded Core modules only happens if the script is launched via the VSCode `PowerShell Integrated Console` (with the installed PowerShell extension), the implicit remoting in every shell.

To get the 2nd error message I ran `Get-Module VMware.VimAutomation.Core` once to load the module.

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

Might be related to https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/15872, but I fear this bug is more fundamental.
When I call
Get-ChildItem -LiteralPath:'\\\\?\\C:\\Program Files' in Powershell Core 7.1.4
it returns all directories and files located on 'C:\\' regardless of what the current work directory is.
As soon as the specified path does not exist, I get the expected error.
E.g. 
Get-ChildItem -LiteralPath:'\\\\?\\C:\\Program Filessssss'
will display error: 'Get-ChildItem: Cannot find path '\\\\?\\C:\\Program Filessssss' because it does not exist.
Get-ChildItem -LiteralPath:'\\\\?\\C:\Program Files' works as expected in Windows Powershell 5.1.
Originally I detected this error with this:
Get-ChildItem -LiteralPath:'\\\\?\\UNC\\autlet\\QA\\TestResults\\Artist'
where '\\\\autlet\\QA\\TestResults\\Artist' is an existing folder on shared drive '\\\\autlet\\QA'.
also for this case Get-ChildItem returns the files and folders from root of drive C:\\.
Also here, if I specify a not existing folder, I get the expected error.
E.g.
Get-ChildItem -LiteralPath:'\\\\?\\UNC\\autlet\\QA\\TestResults\\Artistttt'
will display error  'Get-ChildItem: Cannot find path '\\\\?\\UNC\\autlet\\QA\\TestResults\\Artistttt' because it does not exist.

I'm aware, that this syntax ('\\\\?\UNC\\...' resp. '\\\\?C:\\...') is not documented in the Powershell documentation for Get-ChildItem (https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/microsoft.powershell.management/get-childitem?view=powershell-7.1 - neither for Windows Powershell 5.1 nor for Powershell Core 7.x), but this solution can often be found in the internet when searching for solutions to 'long path' problems.
If this syntax should not be supported, then it should give an error in each case.


### Expected behavior

```console
Get-ChildItem -LiteralPath:'\\?\C:\Program Files'

Should return the files and folders under 'C:\Program Files\'.
```


### Actual behavior

```console
Get-ChildItem -LiteralPath:'\\?\C:\Program Files'

Returns the files and folders under 'C:\'.
```


### Error details

_No response_

### Environment data

```powershell
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.1.4
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.1.4
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.19043
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```


### Visuals

![Powershell Core Get-ChildItem Problem ](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7192499/135046445-36761b3f-df5f-4aa9-beeb-4f39a699eb68.png)
# https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/15872

# PR Summary

Fix #15958
Fix #13365

Change `Target` from a `CodeProperty` to be an `AliasProperty` that points to `FileSystemInfo.LinkTarget`.
Also, keep the public API `InternalSymbolicLinkLinkCodeMethods.GetTarget(PSObject instance)`, but use `FileSystemInfo.LinkTarget` inside.

I have reviewed the .NET implementation of `LinkTarget`, and can confirm that the functionality is in parity.
The only difference is that `LinkTarget` doesn't throw error when the file doesn't exist, but our `GetTarget(...)` throws exception in that case. So, I add the file-existence check at some places, and other places doesn't need the check.

It would be easier to review by ignoring the white-space changes:
https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/pull/16165/files?w=1

body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

The New-Timespan command can support start and end to calculate a span, or days, hours, minutes and seconds, but not ticks or milliseconds. 

[timespan]::new _does_ support ticks, and either hours / mins / seconds , days/hours/mins/seconds or days/hours/mins/seconds/milliseconds. 



### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

Either add a milliseconds parameter OR if seconds is not an integer convert the fraction to milliseconds

Supporting ticks would also be a good addition.

### Steps to reproduce

The function below has no debug output, so I would expect that the `-Debug` switch would have no effect, but it triggers the `-Confirm` prompt.

```
function Test-DebugWithConfirm
{
	[CmdletBinding(
	  SupportsShouldProcess = $true
	, ConfirmImpact         = 'Low'
	)]

	Param ()

	BEGIN
	{
		$confirmImpact = $MyInvocation.MyCommand.ScriptBlock.Attributes | Where-Object { $_ -is [System.Management.Automation.CmdletBindingAttribute] } | Select-Object -ExpandProperty ConfirmImpact
		Write-Host "`$confirmImpact    : $confirmImpact"
		Write-Host "`$ConfirmPreference: $ConfirmPreference"
		Write-Host "`$DebugPreference  : $DebugPreference"
	}

	PROCESS
	{
		If ($PSCmdlet.ShouldProcess('Doing the thing.','Proceed?','Ready to do the thing.'))
		{
			Write-Host 'Doing the thing.' -ForegroundColor Green
		}
	}

	END {}
}
```
Set the `$DebugPreference` variable:
```
PS C:\> $DebugPreference = 'Continue'
PS C:\> Test-DebugWithConfirm
$confirmImpact    : Low
$ConfirmPreference: High
$DebugPreference  : Continue
Doing the thing.
```
So far, so good. Now call with the `-Debug` switch:
```
PS C:\> $DebugPreference = 'SilentlyContinue'
PS C:\> Test-DebugWithConfirm -Debug
$confirmImpact    : Low
$ConfirmPreference: High

Ready to do the thing.
Proceed?
[Y] Yes  [A] Yes to All  [N] No  [L] No to All  [S] Suspend  [?] Help (default is "Y"): y
Doing the thing.

### Steps to reproduce

function Invoke-AddOne {
    param (

}
```

```

If this is a matter of me writing an improper example, please let me know. If this the case and I just need to add `Remove-Variable` to my functions, then my apologies.

### Steps to reproduce

Note: There may be good reasons not to call `Unregister-Event` from inside an `-Action` script block passed to `Register-ObjectEvent`; however:
* A _hang_ still shouldn't occur.
* Guidance should be added to the docs.

The hang seems to occur when more events are pending at the time `Unregister-Event` is called:

```powershell
$timer = [Timers.Timer]::new()
$timer.Interval = 200

$action = {
  Write-Verbose -vb "Timer fired."
  $Event.Sender.Stop()
  Write-Verbose -vb "Timer stopped."
  Unregister-Event theTimer
  Write-Verbose -vb "Event unregistered."
}

$null = Register-ObjectEvent -InputObject $timer -EventName elapsed `
                             –SourceIdentifier thetimer `
                             -Action $action

$timer.Start()

while ($timer.Enabled) {
  # A sleep period of at least twice the timer interval causes a hang.
  Start-Sleep -MilliSeconds 400
}

Write-Verbose -vb 'Done'
```

### Expected behavior

The script should complete.


### Actual behavior

The script hangs after emitting the `Timer fired.` and `Timer stooped.` messages, suggesting that the `Unregister-Event` call is the culprit.

### Error details

_No response_

### Environment data

```powershell
PowerShell Core 7.2.0-preview.9
```

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

Note: 
* This issue has _partly_ been reported before, in the context of #3727, but it's worth creating a focused report.
* The problem affects `-Exclude` too, but use of `-Exclude` with _file_ filters is treacherous and not meaningfully supported.

When you combine `Remove-Item -Recurse` with either `-Include` or `-Filter`, only those items _inside_ the target directory subtree that match the pattern(s) are removed, as intended.

However, if you invoke such a command with `.` as the input path, i.e. from _inside_ the target directory, the command fails, as an attempt is seemingly made to delete the directory _itself_:

```powershell
# Switch to a temporary directory.
Push-Location -ea Stop ($tmpDir = (New-Item -Type Directory -Force (Join-Path Temp:/ $PID)).FullName)

try {

$null = New-Item -Force 1.txt, sub/2.txt

Remove-Item . -Recurse -Filter *.txt

$null = New-Item -Force 1.txt, sub/2.txt

Remove-Item . -Recurse -Include *.txt

} finally {
  # Clean up.
  Pop-Location; Remove-Item $tmpDir -Recurse
}
```

### Expected behavior

Both `Remove-Item` calls should succeed and delete all `*.txt` files from the current dir's subtree.


### Actual behavior

Both commands fail.


### Error details

```none
Cannot remove the item at '<full-path-of-current-dir>' because it is in use.
```


### Environment data

```powershell
PowerShell Core 7.2.0-preview.9
```

The problem also affects Windows PowerShell.

_No response_

### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.

- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

I'm using iTerm2 on macOS 11.8 and pwsh 7.1.4

I noticed an issue when I changed my iTerm default profile to run pwsh directly. Previously it would start zsh and issue the command pwsh, where my `$env:PATH` variable would match the `$PATH` variable of the zsh session that launched it.

When launching pwsh directly, the default `$env:PATH` value is `/usr/local/microsoft/powershell/7:/usr/bin:/bin:/usr/sbin:/sbin` and does not include any of the values specified in `/etc/paths` and `/etc/paths.d/`. 

I created a small workaround for now and added to my profile:
```
# Fix $env:PATH to include system paths. First turn the variable into an array
[System.Collections.ArrayList]$PATH = $env:PATH -split ':'
# Append the system paths 
$PATH += (Get-Content /etc/paths)
$PATH += (Get-ChildItem /etc/paths.d/ | ForEach-Object {Get-Content $_})
#Set the viariable
$env:PATH = ($PATH | Select-Object -Unique) -join ':' 
```

### Expected behavior

```console
$env:PATH should include the system entries from /etc/paths and /etc/paths.d/*, just like zsh (and likely bash) do.
```


### Actual behavior

```console
$env:PATH = /usr/local/microsoft/powershell/7:/usr/bin:/bin:/usr/sbin:/sbin
```

### Steps to reproduce

1. Install latest version of Fedora
2. Download the latest powershell rpm
3. double-click on the rpm.



### Expected behavior

```console
GNOME-Software should not say the package is proprietary.
```


### Actual behavior

```console
GNOME-Software will say the package is proprietary.
Actually it's MIT-licensed, which qualifies as free software.

This confuses users, and might discourage some users from adopting powershell.
```


### Error details

```console
The reason for this is the license field of the official RPM says "MIT License".
It should be "MIT" instead, which is a valid SPDX License Identifier ("MIT License" is not).

```
See: https://github.com/ximion/appstream/issues/359

N/A
```

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

Note: This scenario is exotic, but the motto is: if you allow it syntactically, even though it doesn't make sense, people will try it and wonder why it doesn't work - see [this Stack Overflow question](https://stackoverflow.com/q/69306144/45375).

A `[ref]` type constraint cannot be meaningfully combined with other type constraints (because it is the type of the _value being assigned_ that invariably determines the type argument to the associated generic, non-public type used behind the scenes; also, the resulting instance's `.Value` property is still `object`-typed, so the instance can be modified to contain a value of _any type_).

There already _is_ a check that enforces that _syntactically_:

```powershell
PS> [ref] [string] $foo = '...'

ParserError:
Line |
   1 |  [ref] [string] $foo = '...'
     |  ~~~~~
     | Cannot use [ref] with other types in a type constraint.
```

However, this check isn't being applied to _parameter declarations_, even though it should:

```
function foo {
  param(
      [ref] [string] $Bar
  )
}
```



### Expected behavior

The function declaration should fail.


### Actual behavior

The function declaration unexpectedly succeeds, which is problematic in two respects:

* It makes a false promise of constraining the by-reference value to type `[string]`.

* It _fails_ if you bind the parameter with a _named_ argument, for the reasons detailed by @iisresetme in the answer to the linked Stack Overflow post.

### Error details

_No response_

### Environment data

```powershell
PowerShell Core 7.2.0-preview.9
```


### Visuals

_No response_

```PowerShell
#

""

{
  $a = [Int32]($i / 2)              # Half-to-even rounding is too bad.

  if($a % 2) {$c = "  "} else {$c = " |"}

### Steps to reproduce

Create a script e.g test.ps1 with the following contents

```
Write-Warning "This is a warning"
Write-Progress -Activity "Progress" -PercentComplete 100
Write-Warning "This is a warning"
```

Run this script with the following command `pwsh test.ps1 > mac.txt` on macOS (probably Linux distros as well I just haven't tested)

Run this script with the following command `pwsh test.ps1 > win.txt` on Windows (tested on Windows 10)

I have attached the files that are produced from the commands above.

[mac.txt](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/files/7215286/mac.txt)
[win.txt](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/files/7215287/win.txt)



### Expected behavior

```console
The files contain the same content similar to below as shown in the windows output from above


WARNING: This is a warning
WARNING: This is a warning

```

[win.txt](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/files/7215287/win.txt)


### Actual behavior

```console
Based on the file content above (and linked below) you can see the mac version has lots of whitespace between the two warning messages and the second warning isn't on a new line as expected.

Whereas the file produced on Windows outputs as I expect it to.
```

[mac.txt](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/files/7215286/mac.txt)

### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

I have some username and ssh key pair to authenticate to CentOS machine and currently unable to properly establish session through New-PSSession.

Currently I take ssh key from some other SECURE place, save it, pass path to it into New-PSSession and will dispose it after usage, but New-PSSession complains about ownership of key file. Which will be deleted anyway. For non domain user.

Let the user decide what secure and what is not. 

```
The background process reported an error with the following message: The SSH
     | client session has ended with error message:
     | @@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@ @         WARNING: UNPROTECTED PRIVATE KEY
     | FILE!          @ @@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@ Permissions for
     | 'F:\\Development\\tmp\\private.key' are too open. It is required that your private key files are NOT
     | accessible by others. This private key will be ignored. Load key "F:\\Development\\tmp\\private.key":
```

And now Im going through world of pain of granting Ownership to non-domain user name, like "foobar".
So basically New-PSSession not working for me.


### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

Add -Ignore parameter or explicit -KeyBody or something.

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

Running a powershell script as a systemd service on Debian 11 does not show any of its output in the journal/syslog as viewed via `journalctl`.

1. Create `/usr/local/bin/pwshscript` (`chmod +x`) =>
```powershell
#!/usr/bin/env pwsh
echo foo
```

2. Create `/etc/systemd/system/pwshscript.service` =>
```
[Service]
ExecStart=/usr/local/bin/pwshscript
```

3. Run `systemctl start pwshscript.service`

4. View log output with `journalctl -eu pwshscript.service`

### Expected behavior

The systemd journal should show the output of `foo`

Example from Debian 10:

```console
Sep 22 14:16:56 testbox systemd[1]: Started pwshscript.service.
Sep 22 14:16:56 testbox powershell[1205]: (7.1.4:1:80) [Perftrack_ConsoleStartupStart:PowershellConsoleStartup.WinStart.Informational] PowerShell console is starting up
Sep 22 14:16:56 testbox powershell[1205]: (7.1.4:8:80) [NamedPipeIPC_ServerListenerStarted:NamedPipe.Open.Informational] PowerShell has started an IPC listening thread on process: 1205 in AppDomain: None.
Sep 22 14:16:56 testbox powershell[1205]: (7.1.4:1:80) [Perftrack_ConsoleStartupStop:PowershellConsoleStartup.WinStop.Informational] PowerShell console is ready for user input
Sep 22 14:16:56 testbox pwshscript[1205]: foo
Sep 22 14:16:56 testbox systemd[1]: pwshscript.service: Succeeded.
```


### Actual behavior

The output of `foo` is missing from the journal in Debian 11:

```console
Sep 22 14:20:49 testbox systemd[1]: Started pwshscript.service.
Sep 22 14:20:49 testbox systemd[1]: pwshscript.service: Succeeded.
```

Note that an identical bash script works correctly in Debian 11:

```console
Sep 22 14:21:57 testbox systemd[1]: Started bashscript.service.
Sep 22 14:21:57 testbox bashscript[4403]: foo
Sep 22 14:21:57 testbox systemd[1]: bashscript.service: Succeeded.
```

So it's only PowerShell + Debian 11 that exhibits this behaviour. PowerShell + Debian 10, and Bash + Debian 11, both work as expected.


### Error details

_No response_

### Environment data

Both powershell and powershell-preview were tested, on Debian 10 and 11. Installed via snap package on both for consistency.

```powershell
PS /root> $PSVersionTable

Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.1.4
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.1.4
OS                             Linux 4.19.0-16-amd64 #1 SMP Debian 4.19.181-1 (2021-03-19)
Platform                       Unix
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```

```powershell
PS /root> $PSVersionTable

Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.2.0-preview.9
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.2.0-preview.9
OS                             Linux 4.19.0-16-amd64 #1 SMP Debian 4.19.181-1 (2021-03-19)
Platform                       Unix
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```

body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

I miss the ISE on Windows. It is a cheap and cheerful environment for quick development of small PowerShell scripts. Nothing fancy, just good enough. And significantly better than notepad and even Notepad++ for this purpose.

I realize that most developers will use a big fancy IDE. If you are into system management, that is not likely since you usually have to develop on the server which will eventually run the scripts. Visual Studio is a dramatic overkill for these jobs and it takes far too long to install.

So give us back the PowerShell ISE for Windows, please!

### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

I suspect that you know how to resurrect the PowerShell ISE since it is a past product.

title: The PowerShell ISE

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

Using 'Invoke-WebRequest -UseBasicParsing', the returned BasicHtmlWebResponseObject does not parse \<input\> tags correctly. It assumes they will be closed with a '/\>' or '\</input\>'. However in html, neither the slash nor closing tag is required/legal depending on your html flavour.

The bug is in BasicHtmlWebResponseObject.Common.cs. The s_inputFieldRegex is set to:

`@"<input\s+[^>]*(/>|>.*?</input>)"`

But it should be:

`@"<input\s+[^>]*(/>|>|>.*?</input>)"`

Looking at the history the problem has been there since PowerShell 3.0, and remains unfixed in the latest PowerShell Core.

### Expected behavior

```console
Suppose we will perform an HTTP GET thusly:

`$response = Invoke-WebRequest -UseBasicParsing -Url 'https://localhost/test.html'`

And the returned html is:

`<html><body><input name='foo' value='mcgoo'></body>/</html>`

$response.InputFields should contain 1 element. $response.InputFields.FindByName('foo') should return the element.
```


### Actual behavior

```console
Instead $response.InputFields contains no elements, and $response.InputFields.FindByName('foo') returns $null.
```


### Error details

_No response_

### Environment data

```powershell
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.0.3
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.0.3
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.18363
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```

### Prerequisites

- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

When running a certain script that performs file operations, it happens that `Get-Item` applied to an existing _file_ returns a `DirectoryInfo` object.

Here's the script and sample data:
[Test-Get-Item.zip](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/files/7193633/Test-Get-Item.zip)

Here's the outcome:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12860484/133958057-cbeae10d-8008-4a6c-887c-4fcc4a807dac.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12860484/133958070-3fcbfdd8-82ef-4708-91cb-1c2fb2928d09.png)


Weirdly enough, if the script is debugged and stopped at a breakpoint just after the check for the correct object type, if `Get-Item` is invoked at the debugger prompt, the correct type is returned.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12860484/133957960-164f467f-86a8-48cc-947e-878f47c78bd8.png)

This has only been repro'ed with data residing on _some specific_ Samba-shared network location.

FWIW, the behavior under Windows PowerShell 5.1 is different:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12860484/133958152-d0c735a6-7651-456b-b814-0a3884d44cf3.png)





### Expected behavior

```console
`Get-Item` applied to a file should always return a `FileInfo` object.
```


### Actual behavior

```console
In some undetermined circumstances, `Get-Item` returns a `DirectoryInfo` object.
```


### Error details

_No response_

```powershell
`

### Steps to reproduce

Hey there,

I am trying to mimic user input in `expect` style for `powershell`. Via sending commands to `pwsh`'s `stdin`.
And I don't understand how I actually can be sure that command is done. 

But now exactly I am trying to understand what I need to send powershel to be able to run a next command.

I see that `pwsh` expects that some byte sequences will be given to it as an indication that command is done.
And they different from time to time.

`\u{1b}[11;68R`
`\u{1b}[11;59R`
`\u{1b}[11;19R`

As I guess a line-disciple does this or this is done via your means?

To see what I mean you can use

https://github.com/zhiburt/expectrl/pull/14

and run

```
cargo run --example interact

A prompt printed after typing command + `\r`

### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

Possibly related: #8931

The purpose of `Get-Command -All` is to allow discovery of _shadowed_ commands, i.e. those available in principle, but preempted by a different command of the same name with higher precedence.

While `Get-Command` without `-All` includes commands from modules that are _available via module auto-loading_, even if those modules are not _currently loaded_ (imported), using `-All` unexpectedly excludes commands from non-loaded modules.



```powershell
# Make sure that module  Microsoft.PowerShell.Archive isn't loaded.
Remove-Module -ErrorAction Ignore Microsoft.PowerShell.Archive

# OK, without -All: the Expand-Archive function is discovered even without its module being loaded.
' -- Without -All'
Get-Command Expand-Archive | Out-Host

# Define a dummy function that shadows the one from the Microsoft.PowerShell.Archive module.
function Expand-Archive { 'psych!' }

' -- With -All'
# Now try to discover *both* functions, using -All
Get-Command -All Expand-Archive | Out-Host
```


### Expected behavior

```console
-- Without -All

CommandType     Name                                               Version    Source
-----------     ----                                               -------    ------
Function        Expand-Archive                                     1.2.5      Microsoft.PowerShell.Archive

 -- With -All

CommandType     Name                                               Version    Source
-----------     ----                                               -------    ------
Function        Expand-Archive
Function        Expand-Archive                                     1.2.5      Microsoft.PowerShell.Archive
```


### Actual behavior

```console
-- Without -All

CommandType     Name                                               Version    Source
-----------     ----                                               -------    ------
Function        Expand-Archive                                     1.2.5      Microsoft.PowerShell.Archive

 -- With -All

CommandType     Name                                               Version    Source
-----------     ----                                               -------    ------
Function        Expand-Archive
```

Note how the _available_ - but not loaded - `Export-Archive` function from the `Microsoft.PowerShell.Archive` module is now missing.

### Error details

_No response_

### Environment data

```powershell
PowerShell Core 7.2.0-preview.9
```


### Visuals

_No response_

body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

Some examples with pipes using `tar.exe` and `wsl.exe`

PSVersion    7.1.4

1. Untar and pipe to `wsl.exe`
    ```pwsh
    Measure-Command {
      tar.exe -xf .\Fedora-Container-Minimal-Base-34-1.2.x86_64.tar -O acd0933ef68b42e175d6f6a7d968dc418d7acbb48cf08926b5b109f3699cc368/layer.tar  | 
      wsl.exe --import fed c:\WSL\fed -
      }  | select -exp TotalSeconds ; wsl --unregister fed
    ```
    Output disappointing...
    >```pwsh
    >14,0322798
    >Unregistering...
    >```

1. Now retrying to pass as an array entry:
    ```pwsh
    Measure-Command {
      ,(tar.exe -xf .\Fedora-Container-Minimal-Base-34-1.2.x86_64.tar -O acd0933ef68b42e175d6f6a7d968dc418d7acbb48cf08926b5b109f3699cc368/layer.tar)  | 
      wsl.exe --import fed c:\WSL\fed -
      }  | select -exp TotalSeconds ; wsl --unregister fed
    ```
    the result is better
    >```pwsh
    >8,0986971
    >Unregistering...
    >```
1. But compare to `cmd.exe`
    ```pwsh
    Measure-Command {
      cmd.exe /c 'tar.exe -xf Fedora-Container-Minimal-Base-34-1.2.x86_64.tar -O acd0933ef68b42e175d6f6a7d968dc418d7acbb48cf08926b5b109f3699cc368/layer.tar | wsl.exe --import fed c:\WSL\fed -'
    }  | select -exp TotalSeconds ; wsl --unregister fed
    ```
    Wow!
    >```pwsh
    >0,534397
    >Unregistering...
    >```

Even using "array hack" the performance between cmd and ps pipes is uncomparable.

## Bonustrack
The same using WSL Interop
```bash
time bash -c 'tar -xf ./Fedora-Container-Minimal-Base-34-1.2.x86_64.tar -O acd0933ef68b42e175d6f6a7d968dc418d7acbb48cf08926b5b109f3699cc368/layer.tar  | wsl.exe --import fed "c:\WSL\fed" -'; wsl.exe --unregister fed
```
😬
>
>
>_**real    0m1.809s**_
>user    0m0.060s
>sys 0m0.712s
>Unregistering...

_No response_

<!-- Anything that looks like this is a comment and can't be seen after the Pull Request is created. -->

# PR Summary

This PR improves `Invoke-Command`'s handling of cases that combine `$using:` expressions with variable namespace notation when the `-ComputerName` parameter is used.
Fixes #9204
Fixes #16019 

## PR Context

When the `-ComputerName` parameter is used, `Invoke-Command` is unable to check which version of PowerShell is available on the remote computer and assumes v2.0. Because PowerShell 2.0 can't parse `$using:` expressions, the `ScriptBlock` is modified before sending, with `$using:` variables renamed to replace the `$using:` expression with `$__using_`.  Currently, the code that renames these variables doesn't check whether the variable path is qualified.  In cases where variable namespace notation is used, this code produces variable names like `$__using_env:foo`, preventing the remote computer from parsing the variables correctly.  The changes in this PR add handling for qualified variable paths, producing variable names like `$__using_env_foo`

This PR does not fix all issues with the handling of `$using:` expressions.  Variable names that include special characters still aren't parsed correctly, for instance.  Since a user technically _could_ name a variable `$__using_env_foo`, this might be considered an ["unlikely grey area" breaking change](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/dev-process/breaking-change-contract.md). Long-term, it might be worth reconsidering how `Invoke-Command` handles the `-ComputerName` parameter; always falling back to v2.0 seems unnecessarily restrictive.

## PR Checklist

- [x] [PR has a meaningful title](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-request---submission)

### Steps to reproduce

I have a Rocky Linux 8 installation with powershell 7.1.4. I use powershell for monitoring and run pwsh to get a set of results. I've added opt-out environment variables as following to the systemd.


> systemctl edit zabbix-server

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/microsoft.powershell.core/about/about_telemetry?view=powershell-7.1

Environment=DOTNET_CLI_TELEMETRY_OPTOUT=1

PATH=/usr/local/sbin:/usr/local/bin:/usr/sbin:/usr/bin

### Steps to reproduce

Documentation for the PowerShell SDK is generated from triple-slash comments in the source code. Therefore any changes to that documentation must be made in the source code.

The following files use the `<snippet>` tag in the comments. This tag is not supported and is causing rendering issues.

body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

When running PowerShell within Windows Terminal, one can use OSC9;4 sequences to indicate (on the tab and on the taskbar) that a lengthy command is being executed:

````powershell
Write-Host "`e]9;4;3;100`a"
# something that will take quite some time to run
 Write-Host "`e]9;4;0;100`a"
````

It would be useful to have a built-in mechanism that sets the terminal's progress state "automatically" (should be configurable, of course).

This would give users a "seamless" experience like in any other apps that perform lengthy operations.



### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

This should be done in such a way that it doesn't interfere with a potential future use of OSC9;4 by `Write-Progress` et al. (for instance, there should be some kind of function that computes the desired terminal progress state from a combination of _multiple_ sources).

In https://twitter.com/Steve_MSFT/status/1437467621599768576?s=20 @SteveL-MSFT  suggests:

> Maybe in PS7, if a command takes more than some predetermined time to complete (5 secs?), then the native command processor can set the terminal progress state and reset upon completion?

labels.description: the console experience
labels.name: WG-Interactive-Console

labels.name: Needs-Triage

title: Automatic setting of terminal progress state

It is not clear to me if this is related to #14028.

```
PS C:\src\t> Get-Content -Path .\xxx.txt -Tail 1
w
PS C:\src\t> Get-Content -Path .\xxx.txt -Tail 2
\src\t\where\t.txt,1
now
PS C:\src\t> Get-Content -Path .\xxx.txt | Select-Object -Last 1
now
PS C:\src\t> $PSVersionTable.PSVersion.ToString()
7.1.4
```

The problem also occurs on a somewhat large file.

8861 rows affected)

078861 rows affected)

0000000000000010 65 64 29                                        ed)

          Offset Bytes                                           Ascii

0000000000000000 30 37 38 38 36 31 20 72 6F 77 73 20 61 66 66 65 078861 rows affe

I know the focus is on using Windows Terminal, in which I _can_ specify a powerline font... but can you _please_ add support to `pwsh.exe` for those rare instances in which I actually need to launch it directly? Pretty pwease?

### Prerequisites

- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

If I have a file with a typographic quote:

~~~
DON’T LOOK UP.txt
~~~

### Expected behavior

and I try to tab complete

### Actual behavior

~~~
Get-Content '.\DON’T LOOK UP.txt'
~~~

that looks correct enough, but for some reason, PowerShell thinks a typographic quote is also a **programmatic quote**, and so PowerShell thinks the string ends with the typographic quote. This issue can be fixed two ways:

1. Stop treating typographic quotes as special. Only single quote (U+0027) or double quote (U+0022) should be recognized as string terminators.

2. If typographic quotes are going to be used as programmatic quotes, then in the example above, tab complete should use double quotes instead.

### Environment data

~~~
PSVersion                      7.1.4
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.1.4
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.18363
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}

~~~

body:
# PR Summary

Add benchmark to test compiler performance.
The benchmark uses the `compiler.test.ps1` file in our repo, and try compiling it for every call of `CompileFunction`.

Instead of compile the `compiler.test.ps1` as a whole, the benchmark extracts all top-level functions from the file and compile those functions individually. This is because:
1. when compiling the whole file, all script in functions or scripts blocks are not really compiled because they only get compiled when they get to run.
2. compiling individual functions from the file make it easy to update the benchmarks. For example, adding functions that targets a specific compiler scenario.

## PR Checklist

- [x] [PR has a meaningful title](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-request---submission)
    - Use the present tense and imperative mood when describing your changes

body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

I would like the ability to mark a function as a candidate for JIT prior to execution.

## Use Case
I have a tight loop that calls 5 different methods to perform various parsing functions, most of these involve some type of string manipulation.

In benchmarking these functions (using `Measure-Command`) it is found that on the first run each run of the loop takes approximately 2 milliseconds on my i7-9850H. That might not sound like a whole lot, but this loop is called approximately 30,000 times which results in a runtime of about a minute.

On a second run though (without any code changes) this code runs much faster, about .5 millseconds per loop which results in a runtime of about 15 seconds.

Unfortunately I am unable to share the exact code, and I have had a difficult time creating a small reproducing test case that shows the drastic time differences.

## Research
It is believed that the reason for the differences in runtime is due to the PowerShell Runtime JIT'ing the code in question. There doesn't appear to be any MSDN Documentation on this behavior, rather there are several posts on StackOverflow that describe this:

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/34202462/does-powershell-compile-scripts

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/54434601/powershell-functions-and-performance

However none of these seem to describe any method to try and mark the function as hot to give a hint to the runtime to more eagerly attempt to JIT this.

The ask is two fold:

1. A way to indicate that this function should be optimized as soon as possible
2. Documentation on the JIT behavior

### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

_No response_

body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

`Measure-Object` currently does not have a builtin alias. Suggest that `mo` be added to the built aliases. I did not see any native binary conflicts across Linux (Ubuntu 20.04), Windows, or MacOS (Big Sur).

The following is a bit laborious especially if you run the command first and then decide you wanted the count.

```powershell
(gci -r -file).Count
```

### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

Add `mo` as an alias for `Measure-Object`.

```powershell
gci -r- file | mo
```

### Steps to reproduce

Did an upgrade of 7.1.3 to 7.1.4 yesterday on ubuntu server 20.04 
Installed via the preferred method of adding the repositories to apt.

After install I lost the PSWSMan Modules, which was ok, just installed anew with scope allusers

My script runs on the www-data user, so no home directory and I could not get it to see the modules. 

Turns out that after the upgrade, I had a libmi.so.bak and libpsrpclient.so.bak file and the new libmi.so and libpsrpclient.so had permissions of 640 instead of 644.
(in /opt/microsoft/powershell/7/ )







### Expected behavior

```console
Upgrade of 7.1.3 to 7.1.4 should have set file permissions to 644 to libmi.so and libpsrpclient.so
```


### Actual behavior

```console
Upgrade of 7.1.3 to 7.1.4 set file permissions to 640 to libmi.so and libpsrpclient.so
```

- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

According to the [documentation page for the Out-File cmdlet](https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/PowerShell-Docs/blob/staging/reference/7.1/Microsoft.PowerShell.Utility/Out-File.md), the `-FilePath` parameter does not accept any wildcard characters. Yet, it does! The consequences are dire. Imagine running the following cmdlets:

``` PowerShell
' ' | Out-File -FilePath '.\[1-4].txt'
```

### Expected behavior

I expect `Out-File` to try to create a file called `[1-4].txt`. This is a perfectly valid name in NTFS. If this file exists, overwrite it. This outcome is according to the documentation page too.

### Actual behavior

1. If none of the following files exist: `1.txt`, `2.txt`, `3.txt`, and `4.txt`
    `Out-File` throws the following unreasonable error: "Out-File: Cannot perform operation because the wildcard path .\[1-4].txt did not resolve to a file."
1. If **one and only one** of the following files exist: `1.txt`, `2.txt`, `3.txt`, and `4.txt`
    `Out-File` overwrites the file, unless `-NoClobber` is specified.
    In complex situations, this could cause unexpected loss of data in files that should not be affected.
1. If **more than one** of the following files exist: `1.txt`, `2.txt`, `3.txt`, and `4.txt`
    `Out-File` throws the following unreasonable error: "Out-File: Cannot perform operation because the path resolved to more than one file. This command cannot operate on multiple files."

### Error details

# PR Summary

Fix #14387

Follow up on #14397. These two APIs were previously internal and used by the ConsoleHost.  However, this means that every host would need to have similar code to handle ANSI rendering correctly.  Discussion with @daxian-dbw and @rjmholt was to move them to `PSHostUserInterface` so they can be used by the dotnet-interactive Jupyter kernel and the vscode-powershell extension.
